Seen this before and thought it was fixed. This looks like it may actually be a
JFace problem w/rgs to concurrency access to the viewer.

Unfortunatly then it happens the sync view looks terrible, some nodes may not
have labels... I've seen this before.
*** Bug 57645 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 58142 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

+1, running N200404190010.  Needs to be under pretty hefty load to get there, it seems - updating 
across multiple projects.

Created an attachment (id=10216)
Patch to org.eclipse.jface project

The problem is that JFace disables the label updater when an exception occurs. 
Any subsequent updates result in empty labels and icons. We have not been able 
to reproduce this so we don't know why we are getting a widget disposed. I 
have create a patch to the org.eclipse.jface project that modifies 
AbstractTreeViewer to only disable label updating if the viewer's control is 
disposed. Otherwise, the other label updates are processed.

Moving to UI to consider applying the patch

Nick what is your opinion? This has the side effect of continuing to attempt 
updates even though there is an exception in the code.

I think this is in the spirit of the other code we have done that does not 
shut down events on an exception but I want Nicks opinion.

I've removed the error flag from the UpdateItemSafeRunnables in the viewers.
Label updates are still run in a safe runnable.
This may result in more errors getting logged, but at least the update will
continue to run and have the chance to fail in its own right <g>.
Closing as Nicks changes cover this case.

I'm going to have to re-open this one. I think there is a concurrency hole in
the AbstractTreeViewer. The Synchronize View will generate label updates and
before this happens we check if the viewer is disposed. Once the viewer is
processing the label updates, it finds a tree item that is disposed and crashes.
 May users are seeing this, specifically in the sync view because we add/remove
items from the viewer concurrently.

*** Bug 64978 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

SynchronizeModelProvider$LabelUpdateJob.runInUIThread needs to check that the
viewer's control has not been disposed before telling the viewer to update. 
Viewers themselves should not do this checking.

That was my point - we do check and then tell the viewer to update. We have also
verified that our equals() and hashCode() of the elements in the viewer is
correct. The view is holding on to disposed tree items when the viewer itself is
still valid.

Right, sorry, I missed that in your earlier comment.
Will investigate for RC2.

Does anyone have steps to reproduce this?

As we cannot replicate this I have added code to protect against this case and 
added assertion checks to inform us when it happens.

You will now get the element unmapped for this and an seertion failed. I will 
keep this open however until we find the root of the problem.
*** Bug 68271 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I have improved the handleException method in UpdateItemSafeRunnable to dump 
the details of all disposed widgets when this occurs.
*** Bug 71442 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 73539 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Tod, have a look at the traceback from bug 57093, this contains some of the
assertions you added to tree viewer. I hope it helps you track this one down.
I think Jean-Michel meant bug 73539;-)

After talking to Michael Valenta and John Arthorne the problem here is that 
the CVS decorator is spinning the event loop during decoration (when it is 
getting sync info). Our code needs to protect against user code spinning the 
event loop.

I have added an isDisposed check after the update label in both the TreeViewer 
and the TableViewer so that if a dispose occurs as a result we can abort 
updates.

Although this is not possible to consistently replicate I am going to mark 
this verified.
